name: Blue Light Therapy
summary: A form of phototherapy that uses short-wavelength visible light to influence circadian rhythms, improve mood, and treat certain dermatologic conditions.
description:
Blue light therapy involves exposure to light in the blue spectrum, typically between 450–495 nanometers, which has distinct biological effects compared to full-spectrum or white light. In mental health, blue light is primarily used for circadian rhythm modulation, seasonal affective disorder (SAD) treatment, and sleep-phase disorders by influencing melanopsin-containing retinal ganglion cells that project to the brain's suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN).

In dermatology, high-intensity blue light is employed for its antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties, often in acne treatment or as part of photodynamic therapy for certain precancerous skin lesions. The wavelength and intensity used in psychiatric versus dermatologic applications differ substantially, with psychiatric use focusing on safe daily exposure and dermatologic use often involving shorter, higher-intensity treatments.

metadata.session_duration: 20–40 minutes for psychiatric use; 5–20 minutes for dermatologic use

conditions_treated: Actinic keratosis (as part of photodynamic therapy)
contraindications: Active ocular disease sensitive to light
Use of photosensitizing medications without precautions
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe when used as directed; mild side effects may include eyestrain, headache, or mild agitation. Dermatologic protocols can cause transient erythema or peeling.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong for SAD; moderate for delayed sleep phase; emerging for non-seasonal depression and dermatologic uses.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Multiple randomized controlled trials support efficacy for SAD and circadian rhythm disorders; growing evidence base for dermatologic indications.

sections.text: Blue light stimulates intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells, which send signals to the suprachiasmatic nucleus, the brain's circadian pacemaker. This leads to phase shifts in melatonin secretion and improved alignment of sleep-wake cycles. In dermatology, blue light penetrates the skin and exerts antibacterial effects against Propionibacterium acnes and can activate photosensitizers used in photodynamic therapy.

sections.preparation: Assess for photosensitivity, review eye health history, and determine appropriate light intensity and timing based on target condition.
procedure: Position light source at a specified distance (typically 30–60 cm for psychiatric use).
Expose eyes indirectly to light for prescribed duration while engaging in normal seated activities.
For dermatologic uses, position treatment area under blue light device and follow specific energy-dose protocols.
sections.frequency: Once daily for psychiatric protocols; 1–3 times weekly for dermatologic uses
sections.duration: 2–4 weeks for SAD; ongoing maintenance during at-risk seasons; dermatologic treatment courses vary by condition

items: Blue light therapy box or panel
Photodynamic therapy photosensitizing agents (for dermatologic use)

long_term: Sustained mood stabilization during seasonal risk periods
